answers.answer: Are you on cholesterol medication and are you on a strict diet?  The problem with diabetes is after surgery the body does not heal or does not heal as well.  What happened to a friend of the family who was diabetic and had bypass surgery, is that his heart swelled and they could not get it in his chest.  He died after being removed from life support 3 days after surgery.  Then, the chest does not heal shut and the leg does not heal and infection sets in.  The best thing to do is take some good cholesterol medication statin such as Lipitor.  The studies on Lipitor have shown that it has helped get rid of some of the cholesterol in the arteries.  Be on a very strict diet.  No fast food, no eating out at restaurants, eliminate or extremely limited red meat, no processed foods such as hotdogs or lunch meat, no added salt and no canned vegetables or soups, no doughnuts.  Make everything from fresh.  Salmon is good for the omega 3, brown rice, organic fresh vegetables.  The yellow organic potato is tasty and so good that you can eat it plain without margarine.  Being that you are diabetic any surgery would be a risk.  Take care of yourself, take your medication as prescribed by your doctor, and watch your diet.  Medication does help and has helped several members of our family avoid open heart surgery who were also diabetic.  We have severe coronary artery disease, valve disease, and cardiomyopathy in the family with some family members living to be only 31.  With medication family members are now living to be 75 without surgery.  Take care.

question: I am 41yr old female and I have been diagnoised with Conary Artery Disease, Ischemic Cardiomyopathy and Severe Left ventricular systolic disyfunction and inferior wall and anterior wall myocardial scarring and I am a type II diabetic.    I have had 6 stents placed in my heart,  My doctor wanted me to have bypass surgery, but the surgeon at the hospital said I didn't qualify due to diabetes and I am obese.  I want to know if I would benefit severaly with bypass surgery and would a larger hospital risk it and should I risk it.  I also want to know if there is any other procedures that could be done to help improve my heart function and if I don't have anything done what would be my prognosis and how much time would i have left.  I also want to know if you think I would be a canidate for a heart transplant or would my weight and diabetes prevent this.If my weight would prevent it I wanted to know about if I could have gastric bypass surgery and if that would be the way to go first before proceding with anything else?Thank you for your time.
title: Prognosis of Cardiomyopathy
